parts.text:
A student investigated how the pressure of a gas varied with the volume of the gas. The mass and temperature of the gas were constant.

What is the range of the syringe?
markScheme: Answer: D – 0 to 25 cm³

parts.text: What type of variable was the mass of gas?
markScheme: Answer: A – Control

parts.text: Complete the sentences. Choose the answers from the box. Each answer may be used once, more than once or not at all.
segments: When the gas is compressed, the volume of gas in the syringe

.

This means the force exerted on the inside surface of the container walls

1 mark: **increases**
1 mark: **increases**

parts.text:
A student investigated how the pressure in a fixed mass of air varies with the volume of the air. When the plunger was pushed slowly into the syringe, the temperature of the air stayed the same.

How did pushing the plunger in affect the volume of air in the syringe?
markScheme: Answer: A – The volume decreased

parts.text: How did pushing the plunger in affect the distance between the air particles in the syringe?
markScheme: Answer: A – The distance decreased

parts.text: How did pushing the plunger in affect the frequency of collisions between the air particles and the syringe walls?
options: The frequency of collisions stayed the same.
markScheme: Answer: C – The frequency of collisions increased

parts.text: How did pushing the plunger in affect the air pressure in the syringe?
options: The air pressure stayed the same.
markScheme: Answer: C – The air pressure increased

parts.text:
A fire piston is a special type of syringe that can be used to start fires. The plunger is pushed quickly downwards and compresses the air. When the air is compressed quickly, the temperature of the air increases.

How does an increase in temperature affect the mean speed of the air particles inside the syringe?
options: The mean speed of the particles decreases.
The mean speed of the particles does not change.
The mean speed of the particles increases.
markScheme: Answer: C – The mean speed of the particles increases

parts.text:
A teacher demonstrated the relationship between the pressure and the volume of a fixed mass of gas at a constant temperature.

Complete the sentences. Choose the answer from the box for each sentence.
segments: Particles in a gas move in
markScheme: 1 mark: **random directions**
1 mark: **a range of speeds**

parts.text:
The relationship between the pressure and the volume of a gas is given by the equation:

$$\text{pressure} \times \text{volume} = \text{constant}$$

Table 1 shows some of the results. Calculate the constant when the pressure of the gas was 300 kPa.
markScheme: 1 mark: Correct substitution: $300 \times 10$
1 mark: Final answer: **3000 kPa cm³**

tables.caption: Pressure and volume measurements for a gas

parts.text:
When the volume of the gas increases, the pressure in the gas decreases. The temperature of the gas stays the same.

How does increasing the volume affect each of the following quantities? Tick one box in each row.

rows.label: Mean time between collisions of the particles with the tube

markScheme: 1 mark: Mean time between collisions — Increases
1 mark: Mean distance between particles — Increases
1 mark: Mean speed of particles — Stays the same

parts.text:
The figure below shows a balloon filled with helium gas.

Describe the movement of the particles of helium gas inside the balloon.
markScheme: 1 mark: The particles move with a **range of speeds**
1 mark: The particles move in different / **random directions**

parts.text: What name is given to the total kinetic energy and potential energy of all the particles of helium gas in the balloon?
markScheme: Answer: B – Internal energy

parts.text: Write down the equation which links density, mass and volume.
markScheme: Answer: A – $\rho = \frac{m}{V}$

parts.text:
The helium in the balloon has a mass of 0.00254 kg and a volume of 0.0141 m³.

Choose the correct unit for density.
markScheme: Answer: B – kg / m³

parts.text:
Calculate the density of helium.

Mass of helium = 0.00254 kg
Volume of balloon = 0.0141 m³
markScheme: 1 mark: Correct substitution: $\rho = \frac{0.00254}{0.0141}$
1 mark: Final answer: **0.18 kg/m³**

parts.text:
The photograph below shows a balloon filled with helium gas.

Which statements describe the movement of the gas particles in the balloon?
options: The particles all move in a predictable way.
The particles move at the same speed.
The particles move in circular paths.
The particles move in random directions.
The particles move with a range of speeds.
The particles vibrate about fixed positions.
markScheme: 1 mark: The particles move in random directions
1 mark: The particles move with a range of speeds

parts.text:
The pressure of the helium in the balloon is 100 000 Pa. The volume of the balloon is 0.030 m³.

The balloon is compressed at a constant temperature causing the volume to decrease to 0.025 m³. No helium leaves the balloon.

Calculate the new pressure in the balloon.
markScheme: 1 mark: Correct substitution: $100\,000 \times 0.030 = P_2 \times 0.025$
1 mark: Correct rearrangement: $P_2 = \frac{100\,000 \times 0.030}{0.025}$
1 mark: Final answer: **120 000 Pa**

parts.text:
The temperature of the helium in the balloon was increased. The mass and volume of helium in the balloon remained constant.

Explain why the pressure exerted by the helium inside the balloon would increase.
markScheme: 1 mark: Particles would have a higher (mean) **kinetic energy** (accept higher mean **speed**)
1 mark: Increased number of **collisions** with the walls of the balloon per second (accept greater **frequency** of collisions)
1 mark: Greater **forces** exerted in collisions between particles and balloon walls
1 mark: Greater force exerted on the same **area** (accept description using $P = F/A$)

parts.text:
A teacher demonstrated the relationship between the pressure in a gas and the volume of the gas. This is the method used:

1. Record the initial volume of gas in the syringe and the pressure reading before any weights are attached.
2. Attach a 2.0 N weight to the syringe.
3. Record the volume of the gas and the reading on the pressure gauge.
4. Repeat steps 2 and 3 until a weight of 12.0 N is attached to the syringe.

What was the range of force used?
markScheme: 1 mark: **0 N to 12 N** (accept 2 N to 12 N)

parts.text: Give one control variable in the investigation.
markScheme: 1 mark: **Mass of gas** in the syringe (or **temperature** of the gas)

parts.text:
When the volume of gas in the syringe was 45 cm³, the pressure gauge showed a value of 60 kPa.

Calculate the pressure in the gas when the volume of gas in the syringe was 40 cm³.
markScheme: 1 mark: Correct substitution: $60 \times 45 = P \times 40$
1 mark: Correct rearrangement: $P = \frac{60 \times 45}{40}$
1 mark: Final answer: **67.5 kPa**

parts.text:
When the volume of gas in the syringe increased, the pressure on the inside walls of the syringe decreased.

Explain why.
markScheme: 1 mark: There is **more time** between collisions of particles and the walls of the syringe (or there are **less frequent** collisions)
1 mark: Causing a **lower** (average) force on the walls of the syringe
1 mark: Pressure is the total **force per unit area**

parts.text:
A fire piston is a special type of syringe. When the plunger is pushed quickly, the air is compressed and its temperature increases. When the air is hot enough, a small piece of cotton wool catches fire.

The energy transferred to the air in the piston is 0.0130 J.
The mass of air in the piston is $2.60 \times 10^{-8}$ kg.
Specific heat capacity of air = 1010 J/kg °C

Calculate the temperature change of the air.
markScheme: 1 mark: Correct substitution: $0.0130 = 2.60 \times 10^{-8} \times 1010 \times \Delta \theta$
1 mark: Correct rearrangement: $\Delta \theta = \frac{0.0130}{2.60 \times 10^{-8} \times 1010}$
1 mark: Final answer: **495 °C**

parts.text:
A student investigated how the pressure exerted by a gas varied with the volume of the gas. Figure 1 shows the equipment the student used. A pump was used to compress the gas in a tube. As the volume of the gas decreases, the pressure of the gas increases.

The student only recorded one set of results. Give two reasons why taking repeat readings could provide more accurate data.
markScheme: 1 mark: Can calculate a **mean** (or reduces the effect of **random errors**)
1 mark: Can identify / remove **anomalies** (accept: assess the **repeatability** of the data)

parts.text:
Figure 2 shows the position of the student's eye when taking volume measurements.

Explain what type of error would be caused if the student's eye was not in line with the level of the liquid in the tube.
markScheme: 1 mark: **Random** error (accept a **parallax** error)
1 mark: Because eye position would **not be the same** each time relative to the liquid

parts.text:
If the gas is compressed too quickly the temperature of the gas increases.

Explain how the temperature increase would affect the pressure exerted by the gas.
markScheme: 1 mark: A temperature increase would **increase** the pressure in the tube (even if the volume was constant)
1 mark: Because a higher temperature means higher (average) **kinetic energy** / **speed** of molecules

parts.text:
One of the student's results is given below.
Pressure = $1.6 \times 10^5$ Pa
Volume = 9.0 cm³

Calculate the volume of the gas when the pressure was $1.8 \times 10^5$ Pa. The temperature of the gas was constant.
markScheme: 1 mark: Correct substitution: $1.6 \times 10^5 \times 9.0 = 1.8 \times 10^5 \times V$
1 mark: Correct rearrangement: $V = \frac{1.6 \times 10^5 \times 9.0}{1.8 \times 10^5}$
1 mark: Final answer: **8.0 cm³**

parts.text:
Figure 3 shows a person using a bicycle pump to inflate a tyre. The internal energy of the air increases as the tyre is inflated.

Explain why.
markScheme: 1 mark: **Work is done** on the air (in the tyre)
1 mark: So the **temperature** of the air increases (accept the average **kinetic energy** of the particles increases)

questions.title: Kinetic theory of solids and gases
questions.subject: physics

parts.text:
The information in the box is about the properties of solids and gases.

Solids: have a fixed shape; are difficult to compress (to squash).
Gases: will spread and fill the entire container; are easy to compress (to squash).

Use your knowledge of kinetic theory to explain the information given in the box.

You should consider: the spacing between the particles, the movement of individual particles, and the forces between the particles.
markScheme: 1 mark: In solids, particles are **close together**
1 mark: So there is **no room** for particles to move closer (so hard to compress)
1 mark: In solids, particles **vibrate** about a fixed point
1 mark: There are **strong forces** of attraction between particles in a solid (the forces become repulsive if particles get closer)
1 mark: Particles are strongly held together / not free to move around (so shape is **fixed**)
1 mark: In gases, particles are **far apart**
1 mark: There is **space** between particles (so easy to compress)
1 mark: In gases, particles move **randomly**
1 mark: There are **negligible** / no forces of attraction between gas particles
1 mark: Particles **spread out** in all directions to fill the container

parts.text:
The image below shows air being pumped into a car tyre.

Complete the sentence.
segments: Air particles in the tyre move quickly in
markScheme: 1 mark: **random**

parts.text:
When the tyre is at the correct pressure, pumping more air into the tyre causes the pressure to increase further. The volume and temperature of the air in the tyre do not change.

Explain why the pressure increases as more air is pumped into the tyre.
markScheme: 1 mark: More (air) **particles** in the tyre
1 mark: Greater number of **collisions** with tyre walls per second (accept collisions are more **frequent**)

parts.text:
The air pressure in a car tyre changes if the temperature of the air in the tyre increases.

Explain why.
markScheme: 1 mark: As temperature increases, air particles have greater (mean) **kinetic energy** (accept particles move with greater **speeds** on average)
1 mark: More **collisions** with tyre walls per second (accept collisions are more **frequent**)
1 mark: Greater **force** in each collision (accept greater rate of change of **momentum**)
1 mark: Greater (mean) force per square metre causes greater **pressure** on the wall of the tyre

parts.text:
A student investigated how the pressure of a gas varied with the volume of the gas. The mass and temperature of the gas were constant. Figure 1 shows the equipment the student used.

What is the resolution of the syringe?
markScheme: 1 mark: **1** (cm³)

parts.text:
The student compressed the gas in the syringe and read the pressure from the pressure gauge. Figure 2 shows the student's results.

What conclusion can the student make from the data in Figure 2? Use data from Figure 2 in your answer. Give the reason for your answer.
markScheme: 1 mark: Pressure is **inversely proportional** to volume
1 mark: Data to prove relationship, e.g. $8 \times 200 = 1600$
1 mark: And $10 \times 160 = 1600$ (both products are the **same**)

parts.text: Explain why the pressure in the gas increases as the gas is compressed.
markScheme: 1 mark: As the gas is compressed, the **volume** of gas decreases
1 mark: So there are **more frequent** collisions of gas particles with container walls
1 mark: Each particle collision with the wall causes a **force**
1 mark: So there is a **greater force** on the walls
